---
  description: Create scales for area or radius and then convert them with ggplotly.
  function: scale_size
  permalink: /ggplot2/Scales/scale_size/
  layout: base
  language: ggplot2
  name: scale_size
  reference: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/
---


# Default size plot

<pre class="mcode">
p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, size = hwy)) +
   geom_point()
   
plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>

# Change legend name



<pre class="mcode">
p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, size = hwy)) +
   geom_point()
p <-  p + scale_size("Highway mpg")

plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>

# Change size of shapes



<pre class="mcode">
p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, size = hwy)) +
   geom_point()
p <-  p + scale_size(range = c(0, 10))

plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>

To have zero value to have zero size, use `scale_size_area`:


<pre class="mcode">
p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, size = hwy)) +
   geom_point()
p <-  p + scale_size_area()

plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>

# Making legend more readable

Binning can sometimes make it easier to match the scaled data to the legend


<pre class="mcode">
p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, size = hwy)) +
   geom_point()
p <-  p + scale_size_binned()

plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>

Doing this is  most useful when size is a count, see how difficult it is to read without bins:


<pre class="mcode">
p <-    
 ggplot(mpg, aes(class, cyl)) +
  geom_count() +
  scale_size_area()
  
plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>

# Mapping size to radius

<pre class="mcode">
p <- ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, size = hwy)) +
   geom_point()
p <-  p + scale_radius()

plotly::ggplotly(p)
</pre>
